text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.37.1, Financial Products and Transactions, Financial Products Specialty.
conform to IRM 1.11.2.2.5, Address Management and Internal Controls, content from the old IRM was updated and rearranged as follows:

Old IRM Cite Old Title New IRM Cite New Title New n/a 4.37.1.1.2 Authority 4.37.1.1.4 ResponsibilitiesandOrganiza-tion 4.37.1.1.3 Roles and Re- sponsibilities 4.37.1.1.2 Program Objec- tives 4.37.1.1.4 Program Man- agement and Review New n/a 4.37.1.1.5 ProgramControls 4.37.1.1.3 Acronyms 4.37.1.1.6 Terms and Acronyms

IRM 4.37.1.1: Revised for plain language and changed policy owner to “LB&I Policy under the Strategy, Policy, and Governance office in the Assistant Deputy Commissioner Compliance Integration organization.
IRM 4.37.1.1.3: Roles and Responsibilities revised for plain language.
IRM 4.37.1.2.1: Removed outdated instructions related to ISCP and Form 3210. Added reference to IRM 4.46 for ISCP instructions.
Renumbered Exhibit 4.37.1-3 Acronyms, to Exhibit 4.37.1-2, and updated the table.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS IRM 4.37.1 dated August 12, 2019 is superseded.

Financial products specialists and their managers in Large Business & International (LB&I).
Assistant Deputy Commissioner Compliance Integration
Large Business and International Division
Table of Contents
Sample Financial Products Specialist’s Report Cover Sheet

) Purpose : Deﬁne the Financial Products Specialty (FPS) program. Describe organization of the specialty area and provide roles and responsibilities. Describe how the specialty program coordinates with the LB&I Examination Process (LEP) including issue management and related deﬁnitions. (
) Audience : Financial products specialists and their managers in Large Business & International (LB&I). (
) Policy Owner : LB&I Policy under the Strategy, Policy, and Governance in the Assistant Deputy Commissioner Compliance Integration (ADCCI) zation. (
) Program Owner : Financial Institutions and Products (FIP) is responsible the administration, procedures, and updates related to the FPS program. (
) Primary Stakeholders : LB&I executives, senior managers, frontline program analysts, FPS employees and other IRS employees who may the services of an FP specialist. (
) The FPS Program evolved from tax shelters involving commodity, option government security straddles into a vast array of complex tax issues. (

) FPS can impact all types of tax examinations, including examinations of: a. Individuals b. Partnerships c. Corporations d. Exempt Organizations e. Employee Plans f. Estates/Trusts g. Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) h. Real Estate Mortgage Investment Conduits (REMICs) i. Regulated Investment Companies (RICs) (

) Financial products are instruments utilized in the global marketplace. They include, but are not limited to, conventional ﬁnancial instruments such as: a. Stocks b. Bonds c. Mortgages d. Foreign Currency e. Physical Commodities (

) Financial products also include derivatives of conventional ﬁnancial instru- ments, such as: a. Forward Contracts b. Option Contracts c. Futures Contracts d. Notional Principal Contracts (swaps) e. Stripped Mortgage-Backed Securities f. Structured Notes g. Hybrid and/or Synthetic Securities (
) Derivative securities markets have revolutionized how capital is raised is managed. Financial products are primarily marketed by investment Products Specialty

The FPS Program evolved from tax shelters involving commodity, option and government security straddles into a vast array of complex tax issues.
(3) Financial products are instruments utilized in the global marketplace. They include, but are not limited to, conventional ﬁnancial instruments such as:
Financial products also include derivatives of conventional ﬁnancial instru- ments, such as:
a. Forward Contracts b. Option Contracts c. Futures Contracts d. Notional Principal Contracts (swaps) e. Stripped Mortgage
Backed Securities f. Structured Notes g. Hybrid and/or Synthetic Securities
Derivative securities markets have revolutionized how capital is raised and risk is managed. Financial products are primarily marketed by investment bankers
4.37 Financial Products and Transactions
and securities ﬁrms. Inter-bank lending and borrowing, foreign exchange trading and security sales occur in global markets, twenty-four hours a day. (

) Financial arrangements include re-packaging new products or hedging with existing products. Transactions often arbitrage different tax laws that exist between the U.S. and foreign markets and occur in U.S. and foreign subsidiar- ies or branches. (

) Financial products often involve the ﬁnancing of business or the direct products or services rendered by a business. FPS may also be used to manage direct product risk, for example, the hedging of price changes. (

) Generally, issues center around functions handled by the Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer, Comptroller or any other department responsible for worldwide funding, risk management, investing or reﬁnancing in corporations, rather than the tax department. (

) Financial products tax issues exist for not only the dealer who creates and markets transactions, but also for the customer or end user of the product or transaction. Issues can be geographic. For example, there may be many dealer issues in locations with major ﬁnancial centers and few or no dealer issues in locations where there are no major ﬁnancial markets. (
) Financial product tax issues involve: a. Character b. Amount c. Timing d. Source e. Debt or equity determinations on hybrid ﬁnancial instruments (

) Approaching a ﬁnancial products issue begins with a series of questions such as: • What is the ﬁnancial product? • Where is it traded? • Is it traded on an exchange? • Is it traded at all? • Why was the transaction done? • Who is the taxpayer? (
) By law, the IRS has the authority to conduct examinations under Title

, Internal Revenue Code, Subtitle F - Procedure and Administration, Chapter Discovery of Liability and Enforcement of Title, Subchapter A, Examination and Inspection, which includes but is not limited to: • IRC
, Examination of books and witnesses • IRC
, Time and place of examination Note: Additional information related to conducting examinations is contained in
CFR
, Statement of Procedural Rules. (
) For additional information see IRM
, Examination of Returns, and IRM
, LB&I Examination Process.

) The FPS program provides an organizational structure that is ﬂexible and allows for the timely identiﬁcation and dissemination of information in a uniform and consistent manner. (

) The FPS program is organized under FIP which is within the Enterprise Activi- ties Practice Area of the LB&I Division. The FPS program is responsible for providing technical expertise across all operating divisions. (
) The FPS is supported by Director, Financial Institutions and Products, territory managers (TTM), team managers (TM) and FP specialists located throughout the country. (

) FP specialists are revenue agents who possess broad expertise in tax law who have been given special training in ﬁnancial instruments and terminology, ﬁnancial industry practices and the taxation of ﬁnancial instruments and markets. FP specialists serve as issue team members within the LEP. See
, Issue Team Member Roles and Responsibilities. (

) Within LB&I, the issue-based examination process is intended to facilitate execution and decision making in a collaborative process where all parties work together to resolve issues at the earliest appropriate point in an examina- tion. All practice areas of LB&I share an equal responsibility in conducting a thorough examination. See IRM
, Roles and Responsibilities. (
) All IRS personnel have the responsibility to ensure all taxpayer rights are protected and observed. See IRM
, Taxpayer Rights and Pub
, Your Rights as a Taxpayer. (
) The FIP director provides management oversight of the FPS program and the FIP practice networks. (

) The FIP director ensures the FPS program provides: a. Recommendations for policy and legislative changes. b. Uniform and consistent treatment of industry issues. c. Timely technical assistance to the ﬁeld. d. Financial marketplace research and analysis. (

) The FIP director has a responsibility to: a. Plan for budgeting, staffing and training. b. Develop measures to gauge and monitor program effectiveness. c. Develop and monitor management information systems. d. Coordinate and conduct visits to territories and teams. e. Control nationally coordinated projects. f. Develop and recommend referral criteria. g. Develop position descriptions. h. Maintain a directory of FPS program personnel. (
) The FIP director oversees design and delivery of FPS training programs, in coordination with the Enterprise Talent Development office. (

) To provide FPS program oversight, the FIP director will: a. Issue guidelines and procedures. b. Assist territories to achieve uniform direction. c. Provide technical and administrative assistance when necessary. Products Specialty
page (

The FPS is supported by Director, Financial Institutions and Products, territory managers (TTM), team managers (TM) and FP specialists located throughout
The FIP director oversees design and delivery of FPS training programs, in coordination with the Enterprise Talent Development office.
d. Resolve differences between territories/operating divisions. e. Act as liaison between the ﬁeld and other national functions. (
) The FIP director communicates directly with the Financial Products TTMs TMs when warranted. (

) Additional FIP director responsibilities include: a. Plan the expansion of FPS to improve efficiency. b. Ensure matters of importance related to the FPS program are timely brought to the attention of the FIP director, including recommendations for improvement. c. Promote effective communication within the FPS program regarding ﬁnancial product tax issues. Products (
) A FP TTM is responsible for their respective territory to achieve maximum zation of specialist staff days and case coverage. (
) A TTM periodically conducts workload studies to determine the number and location of FP specialists needed for their territory. (

) The following duties are speciﬁc to how a TTM supports the FPS program within their territory. a. Issue written FPS program procedures. b. Provide for adequate training, both internal and external. c. Conduct periodic group and case visits to evaluate the effectiveness the FPS program. d. Ensure teams within the territory are responding timely to mandatory voluntary case referrals. e. Ensure FPS team managers and specialists are actively engaged in examination process. f. Ensure the director is timely informed of the status of all FPS program projects including those crossing territory lines. g. Ensure the FPS program data contained in various information systems is complete, accurate and updated timely. h. Provide new FPS team managers and specialists with managerial and technical assistance, as applicable, including on-the-job training. i. Ensure the FPS team managers timely evaluate their FP specialists. j. Adhere to IRM
, Principles of Collaboration. Products Team (
) The FP TM will follow the fundamental responsibilities provided in: a. IRM
, Management Roles and Responsibilities. b. IRM
, Issue Manager Roles and Responsibilities. c. IRM
, Manager of Team Members Who Are Not Designated as Case Manager or Issue Manager. d. IRM
, Principles of Collaboration. (

) In addition, the FP manager will: a. Advise the FP TTM of staffing, funding, and training needs. b. Support the LB&I issue selection and collaboration process (ISCP). c. Timely assign or reject referrals on the Specialist Referral System d. Ensure FP referrals are addressed as early as possible and that FP cialist participation does not delay completion of the examination.

e. Timely update and verify the accuracy of data in information reporting systems. f. Communicate to the director, through the TTM, any new or unusual tax issues, examination techniques and tax avoidance schemes as soon as they are discovered or developed. g. Ensure the QRA auditing standards are followed and measurements monitored. h. Support local Appeals and Counsel offices with FP specialists when required, for example for litigation support. i. Evaluate FP specialists timely. j. Encourage regular written feedback from the referring team or group manager regarding the performance of the FP specialists assigned to a case. k. Be involved in the FP portion of cases including, where possible and if schedule permits, case visits, exam planning meetings, mid

cycle reviews, issue resolution meetings with the taxpayer, and post audit critique meetings. l. Ensure FP specialists complete all required examination steps and forms, including audit plans, risk analyses, examination reports, and post audit critiques. m. Review and approve all required forms and reports to be issued. n. Ensure FP specialists correctly report all time related to their assigned cases. o. Provide knowledgeable FP specialists to teach training classes for FP program training and for awareness training for other IRS personnel. p. Ensure key FP issues are coordinated with the corresponding practice networks.

) FP specialists have the following duties and responsibilities: a. Provide specialized technical expertise to all business units within the IRS. b. Provide accountability for efficient, objective and professional expertise leading to the timely completion and resolution of ﬁnancial product tax issues. c. Participate as a team member in the examination process, which planning the examination, performing risk analyses, prioritizing issues, and determining the time required. d. Attend meetings with the examination team and taxpayer, as necessary. e. Prepare and discuss information document requests with the taxpayer. f. Work with the team manager, team coordinator, and other team members or revenue agents to develop and resolve ﬁnancial product tax issues. g. Work to resolve conﬂicts within the team and elevating conﬂicts, as necessary, to the FP team manager. h. Provide feedback about the examination to the FP team manager. i. Coordinate with the corresponding practice networks, the Office of Chief Counsel, and the Office of Appeals, as needed. j. Adhering to IRM
, LB&I Examination Process. (
) For LB&I cases, FP specialists will adhere to IRM
, Issue Team Member Roles and Responsibilities and generally to IRM
, LB&I Examina- tion Process.

Attend meetings with the examination team and taxpayer, as necessary. e. Prepare and discuss information document requests with the taxpayer. f. Work with the team manager, team coordinator, and other team members or revenue agents to develop and resolve ﬁnancial product tax issues. g. Work to resolve conﬂicts within the team and elevating conﬂicts, as necessary, to the FP team manager. h. Provide feedback about the examination to the FP team manager. i. Coordinate with the corresponding practice networks, the Office of Chief Counsel, and the Office of Appeals, as needed. j. Adhering to IRM
, LB&I Examination Process. For LB&I cases, FP specialists will adhere to IRM
, Issue Team Member Roles and Responsibilities and generally to IRM
, LB&I Examina- tion Process.

) The role of the FP High Income Initiative (HII) Cadre is to assist examiners addressing Financial Products related questions and identify the most effective resources available to address identiﬁed issues. (
) Resources may include inquires to the Financial Institution and Products Practice Network or referrals to assign a Financial Products agent to the case. (

) The FPS program seeks to identify, develop, and resolve ﬁnancial products issues that are: a. National in scope b. Signiﬁcant in dollars c. Important to tax administration d. Important for uniform and consistent treatment (

) FPS participates in the LB&I Examination Process (LEP), generally as issue team members and issue team managers. FPS collaborates with the geo- graphic practice area managers in review of potential tax risks and performs timely, effectively planned and managed examinations of ﬁnancial products transactions providing for quality results and minimization of burden to the Internal Revenue Service and to taxpayers. (
) FPS accumulates and disseminates to the ﬁeld examination techniques, infor- mation about tax avoidance and evasion schemes, and other information useful in planning and conducting examinations. (
) FPS monitors the progress and results of issues through various information management systems. (

) FPS works closely with geographic practice area exam teams, international examiners, subject matter experts within the practice networks, and the Office of Chief Counsel in order to achieve FPS objectives and goals. (

) The Issue Management System (IMS) is a case management application sponsored by LB&I. IMS provides case management functionality to LB&I, SB/SE speciality groups, and Appeals. IMS is used to monitor various elements of FPS inventory. For example, Information Document Requests ((IDRs), approving examination plans, risk analysis, and Notice of Proposed Adjustment (NOPAs). (

) FP management periodically reviews reports using the Issue Based Manage- ment Information System (IBMIS). IBMIS is a reporting tool containing day-to- day information gathered on the Audit Information Management System (AIMS). The system provides team managers, territory managers, executives and analysts a centralized system for managing case information for tracking, planning, and reporting. (

, Acronyms, for a list of commonly used acronyms.

/Pages/Default.aspx . Procedures FP (
) Financial Products Specialty workload is assigned through the Specialist Referral System (SRS). Instructions and criteria for mandatory referrals are located on the SRS website. (
) Financial Products Specialty workload is identiﬁed through various processes. a. Cases may be identiﬁed by case managers or their designee. See IRM
, LB&I Examination Issue Selection and Collaboration Process (ISCP) and IRM

, Specialist Referrals. b. If a revenue agent starts a case without an FP specialist already assigned, the revenue agent can make a referral to FP in the SRS. c. For workload identiﬁed through the campaign selection process, the FP specialist will be involved in various campaigns on an as-needed basis. Specialist (
) Large Corporate Compliance (LCC) cases are a mandatory FPS referral at beginning of the examination to allow the Financial Products specialist to par- ticipate during the planning phase. (
) HII cases are a mandatory FP SRS referral for all new starts, including related pick-ups, as of June
Financial Products Specialty workload is identiﬁed through various processes.
a. Cases may be identiﬁed by case managers or their designee. See IRM
, LB&I Examination Issue Selection and Collaboration Process (ISCP) and IRM

, Specialist Referrals. b. If a revenue agent starts a case without an FP specialist already assigned, the revenue agent can make a referral to FP in the SRS. c. For workload identiﬁed through the campaign selection process, the FP specialist will be involved in various campaigns on an as-needed basis.
) Large Corporate Compliance (LCC) cases are a mandatory FPS referral at the beginning of the examination to allow the Financial Products specialist to par- ticipate during the planning phase. (
) HII cases are a mandatory FP SRS referral for all new starts, including related pick-ups, as of June
Note: Notate on the SRS Referral “HII case - mandatory referral required.”

) The FPS program encourages referrals. Returns not requiring mandatory referrals may be referred if FP specialist assistance is appropriate. Examiners should make referrals as early as possible upon identiﬁcation of a ﬁnancial products issue. Informal assistance is available to determine if a referral be made. Informal assistance may not be used in lieu of mandatory referral requirements. (
) Although not identiﬁed as mandatory referrals on SRS, the FPS program rec- ommends that CBF assignments be made for Form
partnerships and joint ventures with assets greater than $
million in order for an initial risk sessment to be conducted. (
) This subsection covers the preparation, review and routing of the FP special- ist’s report. (
) FP specialists will follow IRM
, Workpaper Organization and Consider- ations. This includes the WP Naming Convention and the requirement to documents uploaded to IMS. (
) Upon completing an assignment, the FP specialist will prepare an FP special- ist’s report. The report will be prepared for all referrals, including no changes.
Upon completing an assignment, the FP specialist will prepare an FP special- ist’s report. The report will be prepared for all referrals, including no changes.

) The FP specialist’s report will use the proper forms required in IRM
, Workpaper and Reports Resources, and IRM
, Report Writing, depending on the nature of the referral. (
) The FP report must include a cover sheet, listing administrative data such as date started, date completed, time charged and proposed adjustments by UIL code and disposition. See Exhibit
for a sample FP specialist’s report cover sheet. Note: There are a variety of formats for this cover sheet that may be in use. The cover sheet in Exhibit
is just one example.
) Reviewing and Routing FP Specialist’s Report (
) The FP specialist’s report will be routed to the FP team manager for review and approval. (
) The FP team manager, or designee, will review and approve the FP special- ist’s report promptly (generally within ﬁve business days) to avoid any delay in disposition and closure of the case. (
) The ﬁnal FP specialist’s report will be forwarded to the referring manager.
